ygData.subject: Re: [cantera] python installation trouble
ygData.msgSnippet: Ulf, Regarding the first error, it looks like it cannot find file gri30.cti. Note that a file .cttmp.py  is created that contains the commands that it was

Ulf,

Regarding the first error, it looks like it cannot find file gri30.cti. 
Note that a file .cttmp.py  is created that contains the commands that 
it was trying to execute when it failed.
So try double-clicking on this file to run it, or at a command-line 
prompt in this directory type

python .cttmp.py

The resulting error message will tell you what is wrong.  If it is not 
finding gri30.cti, then one fix is to move this file (in the data 
folder) into the folder where you are running the example.  If you are 
trying to use Cantera on a machine running Windows 98 or Windows ME, 
this problem is bound to occur, because the environment variable 
COMMONPROGRAMFILES, which is supposed to be defined by the OS (and is 
in Windows XP and 2000), is not defined. On Windows PCs (only), Cantera 
uses this environment variable to look for where the data files are 
installed.  (This could probably be done better using the Registry, but 
I don't know how to do that and don't really want to learn... If anyone 
in the user's group has experience with accessing the Registry from 
C/C++, file 'misc.cpp' in the Cantera C++ source code is where the 
default data directory locations are set.)

As far as the second error, the equilibrium routine now considers it an 
error if the temperature goes outside the range for which the thermo 
data are valid for all species. If you look in gri30.cti, you will see 
that data for CH3O are only provided up to 3000 K.  When this range was 
exceeded, an error was flagged.  The way it is implemented in 
ChemEquil.cpp has a problem, though, and will be changed. Currently if 
the initial estimate is outside the range, this is considered an error. 
But of course it should only be an error if the final converged value 
is outside the range.  The next  release will fix this.  The workaround 
is to change the upper temperature limit for CH3O.

Dave


On Mar 15, 2004, at 10:49 AM, usenechal wrote:

> Dear Prof. Goodwin,
>
> I just installed Cantera153.msi and tried the reactor1.py for testing
>  (I changed  I get an error :
>
> ------------start error message 1-----------------------------
> Traceback (most recent call last):
>   File "C:\Programme\Cantera153\demos\Python\reactor1.py", line 11, in 
> ?
>     gri3 = GRI30()
>   File "C:\PROGRA~1\Python23\Lib\site-packages\Cantera\gases.py", line
> 33, in GRI30
>     return Solution(src="gri30.cti", id="gri30")
>   File "C:\PROGRA~1\Python23\Lib\site-packages\Cantera\solution.py",
> line 40, in __init__
>     root = XML.XML_Node(name = 'doc', src = src, preprocess = 1)
>   File "C:\PROGRA~1\Python23\Lib\site-packages\Cantera\XML.py", line
> 35, in __init__
>     self._xml_id = _cantera.xml_get_XML_File(src)
> error:
> Procedure: ct2ctml
> Error:   could not convert input file to CTML
>  command line was: c:/python23/python ./.cttmp.py> ct2ctml.log 2>&1
> Error in Python installation.
> ------------end error message 1-----------------------------
>
> When I modify the python-file to use
> "gri3=IdealGasMix('gri30.xml','gri30')" instead of "gri3 = GRI30()"
> the error changes to:
> ------------start error message 2-----------------------------
> Traceback (most recent call last):
>   File "C:\Programme\Cantera153\demos\Python\reactor1.py", line 15, in 
> ?
>     gri3.equilibrate('HP')
>   File
> "C:\PROGRA~1\Python23\Lib\site-packages\Cantera\ThermoPhase.py", line
> 256, in equilibrate
>     _cantera.thermo_equil(self._phase_id, ixy)
> error:
> Procedure: ChemEquil
> Error:   Temperature (3028.9 K) outside valid range of 300 K to 3000 K
> ------------end error message 2-----------------------------
>
> This temperature seems to be wrong compared with former
> cantera-releases, so what are these errors ? Manually compiling
> cantera for python (with cygwin) gives the same result (with python
> for cygwin). Thanks a lot for your patience.
>
> best regards
> ulf
